elements.content: Seven coordination polymers with 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid (H3pdc) and bridging triazolyl ligands, [Ni3(pdc)2(btb)2(H2O)6] n (1), [Zn2(Hpdc)2(btb)(H2O)2] n (2), {[Ni3(pdc)2(bth)(H2O)8]·2DMF} n (3), [Ni(Hpdc)(bth)] n (4), [Ni3(pdc)2(bth)3(H2O)4] n (5), [Ni(Hpdc)(bth)(H2O)] n (6), and {[Zn(Hpdc)(bth)(H2O)]·2H2O} n (7) (btb = 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane, bth = 1,6-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)hexane), have been hydrothermally or solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. Complexes 1, 3, and 4 are all one-dimensional chain coordination polymers. The structure of 2 comprises herringbone-like two-dimensional 63 nets. 5 possesses a six-connected self-penetrated three-dimensional (3D) architecture with 44.610.8 topological symbol. Complexes 6 and 7 have a similar 3D framework and can be simplified as a four-connected 66 topological network. However, because of the flexibility of the bth ligands in conformations, homochiral helical and meso-helical chains are formed by metal ions and bth ligands in 6 and 7, respectively. The magnetic properties of compounds 1, 3, 5, and 6 are investigated over the temperature range of 1.8−300 K.

The magnetic properties of compounds 1, 3, 5, and 6 are investigated over the temperature range of 1.8-300 K.

elements.content: Under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions, seven coordination polymers have been synthesized and structurally characterized. Complexes 1, 3, and 4 are all one-dimensional chain coordination polymers. The structure of 2 comprises herringbone-like two-dimensional 63 nets. 5 possesses a six-connected self-penetrated three-dimensional (3D) architecture with 44.610.8 topological symbol. Complexes 6 and 7 have a similar 3D framework; however, 6 is a chiral compound, and 7 is a mesomeric compound. Magnetic properties for complexes 1, 3, 5, and 6 have been studied and ferromagnetic interactions were observed for 6.

elements.content: Coordination polymers have attracted much interest because of their intriguing structural topologies and interesting applications as functional materials in catalysis, optics, magnetism, molecular architectures, materials chemistry, etc. The solid-state structures of coordination polymers depend on several factors, such as the coordination nature of ligand, the solvent systems, counterions, and so on. elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers have attracted much interest because of their intriguing structural topologies and interesting applications as functional materials in catalysis, optics, magnetism, molecular architectures, materials chemistry, etc. The solid-state structures of coordination polymers depend on several factors, such as the coordination nature of ligand, the solvent systems, counterions, and so on. Undoubtedly, the ligand is the key factor for manipulating the topologies of coordination polymers. The flexible ligands could bend or rotate to adopt the appropriate conformations and hold the energetic minimum when coordinating to the metal centers, which often causes structural diversity.

elements.content: The flexible bis(N-coordinating heterocyclic ring) ligands containing a 1- or 2-substituted tetrazole, 1-substituted imidazole, benzimidazole, benzotriazole or 1,2,3-triazole, and 1- or 4-substituted 1,2,4-triazole rings tethered by an alkyl spacer have been extensively used, due to their abilities to form the complexes with peculiar properties and/or novel topologies. For example, 1,n-bis(tetrazol-1-yl)alkane (nditz, n = 4−9), 1,3-bis(tetrazol-2-yl)propane (pbtz), 4-bis(1,2,3-triazol-1-yl)butane (bbtr), 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzimidazole (bbbm), 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis-1H-benzotriazole (bbbt), and 1,1′-(1,3-propylene)-bis-1H-benzotriazole (pbbt), etc. have been exploited to construct metal complexes with interesting spin-crossover or third-order nonlinear optical properties. In order to further investigate the influences of the flexibilities of the ligands on the architectures of coordination polymers, in this paper, we choose the flexible bridging ligands (1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane, btb; or 1,6-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)hexane, bth) and the auxiliary ligand 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid (H3pdc) (Scheme ). Herein, the syntheses, crystal structures, and magnetic properties of seven coordination polymers obtained under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions: [Ni3(pdc)2(btb)2(H2O)6] n (1), [Zn2(Hpdc)2(btb)(H2O)2] n (2), {[Ni3(pdc)2(bth)(H2O)8]·2DMF} n (3), [Ni(Hpdc)(bth)] n (4), [Ni3(pdc)2(bth)3(H2O)4] n (5), [Ni(Hpdc)(bth)(H2O)] n (6), and {[Zn(Hpdc)(bth)(H2O)]·2H2O} n (7) are presented.

All chemicals were reagent grade and used as received. The ligands btb and bth were prepared by modified literature methods. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Vector22 Bruker spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400−4000 cm−1 region. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Shimadzu XD-3A X-ray diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were collected on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 TGA analyzer from room temperature to 750 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen. The circular dichroism spectra were recorded on a JASCO J-810 spectropolarimeter with KBr pellets. The second-order nonlinear optical effect was determined on a LAB130 Pulsed Nd:YAG laser. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of polycrystalline samples were measured over the temperature range of 1.8−300 K with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Syntheses

All chemicals were reagent grade and used as received. The ligands btb and bth were prepared by modified literature methods. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240C analyzer. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Vector22 Bruker spectrophotometer with KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Shimadzu XD-3A X-ray diffractometer. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were collected on a Perkin-Elmer Pyris 1 TGA analyzer from room temperature to 750 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C/min under nitrogen. The circular dichroism spectra were recorded on a JASCO J-810 spectropolarimeter with KBr pellets. The second-order nonlinear optical effect was determined on a LAB130 Pulsed Nd:YAG laser. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of polycrystalline samples were measured over the temperature range of 1.8-300 K with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer.

elements.content: A mixture of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.3 mmol, 87.3 mg), H3pdc (0.2 mmol, 34.8 mg), btb (0.2 mmol, 38.4 mg), NaOH (0.2 mmol, 8 mg), H2O (6 mL), and acetone (2 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined bomb and heated at 110 °C for 3 days. The reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were isolated in 76% yield. Anal. calcd. for C26H38N16Ni3O14: C, 32.04; H, 3.93; N, 22.99%. Found: C, 31.94; H, 4.02; N, 22.86%. IR (KBr)/cm−1: 3414 s, 1636 m, 1616 s, 1511 w.

elements.content: The crystal structures of complexes 1−7 were determined on a Siemens (Bruker) SMART CCD diffractometer using monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined using SAINT on all observed reflections. Data were collected using a narrow-frame method with scan widths of 0.30° in ω and an exposure time of 10 s/frame. The highly redundant data sets were reduced using SAINT and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS supplied by Bruker. Structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXL-97. The positions of the metal atoms and their first coordination spheres were located from direct-method E maps; other non-hydrogen atoms were found using alternating difference Fourier syntheses and least-squared refinement cycles and, during the final cycles, were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated position and refined as riding atoms with a uniform value of U iso. Crystallographic details have been summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles and hydrogen-bonding geometry parameters for 1−7 are listed in the (Tables S1 and S2).

X-ray Crystallography

The crystal structures of complexes 1-7 were determined on a Siemens (Bruker) SMART CCD diffractometer using monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Cell parameters were retrieved using SMART software and refined using SAINT on all observed reflections. Data were collected using a narrow-frame method with scan widths of 0.30° in ω and an exposure time of 10 s/frame. The highly redundant data sets were reduced using SAINT and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. Absorption corrections were applied using SADABS supplied by Bruker. Structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXL-97. The positions of the metal atoms and their first coordination spheres were located from direct-method E maps; other non-hydrogen atoms were found using alternating difference Fourier syntheses and least-squared refinement cycles and, during the final cycles, were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated position and refined as riding atoms with a uniform value of U iso. Crystallographic details have been summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles and hydrogen-bonding geometry parameters for 1-7 are listed in the  (Tables S1 and S2).

Complexes 1−7 were obtained under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions. Complexes 1−6 are stable in air, but 7 easily loses the solvated water molecules when exposed to the air. Complexes 6 and 7 possess a similar 3D framework, while 6 is chiral and 7 is mesomeric. The crystals as prepared for 6 are the racemic product, although each single crystal is chiral with right-handedness or left-handedness. The single crystal is very small, and no signal in solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy for powder sample of 6 is observed. According to the principle proposed by Kurtz and Perry, we estimated the second-order nonlinear optical effect of complex 6, and it shows an second harmonic generation (SHG) efficiency with a value of 0.3 times that of urea. Attempts to isolate the Zn(II) chiral structure similar to 6 or the Ni(II) meso-structure similar to 7 are not successful.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparations of 1-7 

Complexes 1-7 were obtained under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions. Complexes 1-6 are stable in air, but 7 easily loses the solvated water molecules when exposed to the air. Complexes 6 and 7 possess a similar 3D framework, while 6 is chiral and 7 is mesomeric. The crystals as prepared for 6 are the racemic product, although each single crystal is chiral with right-handedness or left-handedness. The single crystal is very small, and no signal in solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy for powder sample of 6 is observed. According to the principle proposed by Kurtz and Perry, we estimated the second-order nonlinear optical effect of complex 6, and it shows an second harmonic generation (SHG) efficiency with a value of 0.3 times that of urea. Attempts to isolate the Zn(II) chiral structure similar to 6 or the Ni(II) meso-structure similar to 7 are not successful.

elements.content: The X-ray crystallographic analysis reveals that 1 exhibits a 1D square-chain structure. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains two crystallographically independent nickel ions (Ni(1) and Ni(2)), a pdc3− ligand, a btb ligand and three coordinated water molecules (Figure ). The pdc3− ligand acts in a μ4-η2N,O, η2N′,O′ fashion (Scheme a), chelating to Ni(1) and Ni(2) centers, respectively. Two pdc3− ligands chelate to three nickel ions to form the linear trinuclear Ni(II) units with the central Ni(1) ion on an inversion center, in which the three Ni(II) ions are arranged in a strict linear fashion with an angle of 180° for Ni(2)−Ni(1)−Ni(2a) and a distance of 4.529(4) Å for Ni(1)···Ni(2). Each trinuclear Ni(II) unit is almost planar with the largest deviation of 0.102 Å for Ni(2) atom from the mean plane defined by the pyrazole rings. The Ni(1) and Ni(2) centers are both six-coordinated and have distorted octahedral coordination environments. The coordination spheres of the terminal Ni(2) ions are completed by three oxygen atoms (O(5), O(6), and O(7)) from three water molecules and a nitrogen atom (N(3)) from a btb ligand in the axial position, while for the central Ni(1) ion it is completed by two nitrogen atoms (N(8) and N(8a)) from two btb ligands in the axial position. The Ni−N bond lengths range from 2.039(3) to 2.094(3) Å and the Ni−O bond lengths range from 2.011(2) to 2.165(2) Å, which are all similar to those values found in other Ni(II) complexes.

elements.content: Each bridging btb ligand adopts gauche−trans−gauche conformation (Scheme d) and links to two different trinuclear Ni(II) units. The dihedral angle between two triazole rings of btb is 12.6°. Each trinuclear Ni(II) unit connects with four btb ligands, which pair off and act as double bridges, and therefore the 1D square-chains are formed along the (1 1 0) and (1̅ 1 0) directions (Figure ). The 1D square-chains along the same direction are further connected by hydrogen-bonding interactions (C(9)−H(9A)···O(1d), C(11)−H(11B)···O(1f) and C(10)−H(10B)···O(3e)) to lead to a 2D supramolecular network in the ab plane. These 2D supramolecular networks are packed along the c axis through the O(6)−H(6A)···O(4c), O(7)−H(7B)···O(2b), and O(5)−H(5A)···O(1b) hydrogen-bonding interactions in the ···ABAB··· stacking sequence to form a 3D supramolecular architecture ().

elements.content: Complex 2 possess a herringbone-like 2D network. There are a zinc ion, a coordinated water molecule, an Hpdc2− ligand, and a half of btb ligand in the asymmetric unit (Figure ). Each zinc ion is five-coordinated by O(4) and N(2) from an Hpdc2− ligand in a chelating coordinate mode, O(1a) from another Hpdc2− ligand, N(3) from a btb ligand, and a water molecule O(5). The coordination geometry around the zinc ion can be described as distorted trigonal bipyramid. The Zn−N bond lengths (2.017(8)−2.019(7) Å) and Zn−O bond lengths (1.973(7)−2.265(6) Å) are comparable to those reported values.

Structure of {[Ni<sub>3</sub>(pdc)<sub>2</sub>(bth)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>]·2DMF}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

Complex 3 is a 1D coordination polymer. Two crystallographically independent nickel ions (Ni(1) and Ni(2)), a pdc3− ligand, half of a btb ligand, four coordinated water molecules and a solvated DMF molecule exist in the asymmetric unit (Figure ). Very similar to complex 1, the pdc3− ligands in 3 act in a μ4-η2N,O, η2N′,O′ fashion (Scheme a), chelating to Ni(1) and Ni(2) centers, respectively, leading to strict linear trinuclear Ni(II) units with a Ni(1)···Ni(2) distance of 4.490(3) Å. The deviations from the mean plane defined by the pyrazole rings for Ni(1) and Ni(2) atoms are −0.278 and 0.471 Å, respectively. The two nickel centers are both six-coordinated and have distorted octahedral coordination environments. The remaining coordination sites are occupied by N(3) and N(3a) from two btb ligands for Ni(1), and four oxygen atoms (O(5), O(6), O(7), and O(8)) from four water molecules for Ni(2). Each ligand bth connects two parallel trinuclear Ni(II) units by its two 4-position nitrogen atoms of triazole rings coordinating to the central Ni(1) ions to form a 1D chain structure (Figure ). The 1D chains are connected by the O(5)−H(5B)···O(2c) hydrogen bonds to form the 2D supramolecular nets, which are further linked by the O(6)−H(6A)···O(4d), O(7)−H(7B)···O(1f), O(7)−H(7B)···O(2f), and O(7)−H(7A)···O(8e) hydrogen-bonding interactions in sequence ···ABAB··· to construct a 3D supramolecular architecture (). The btb ligand adopts gauche−trans−trans−trans−gauche conformation (Scheme e) and its two triazole rings are parallel.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 4 contains a nickel ion, an Hpdc3− ligand and a bth ligand (Figure ). Two Hpdc2− ligands in a μ4-η2N,O, η2N′,O′ fashion (Scheme a) chelate to two nickel ions to form a dinuclear Ni(II) unit with a Ni···Ni distance of 4.072(6) Å, which is shorter than that in the linear trinuclear Ni(II) units in 1 and 3. Each Ni(1) center has a distorted octahedral coordination environment and is six-coordinated by N(2), N(2a), O(4), and O(4a) from two Hpdc2−, N(3) and N(8) from two trans-bth ligands. Each dinuclear Ni(II) unit is linked to other two neighboring dinuclear Ni(II) units by four bth ligands in a double-bridged fashion to form ladder-like chains (Figure ). The chains are connected through the O(1)−H(1)···O(4b) hydrogen bonds to form a 2D supramolecular networks in the bc plane. These 2D supramolecular networks are linked along the a axis by the C(14)−H(14)···O(1e), C(13)−H(13A)···O(3d), and C(6)−H(6)···O(3c) hydrogen-bonding interactions to construct a 3D supramolecular framework (). The btb ligand adopts trans−trans−trans−trans−trans conformation (Scheme f) and its two triazole rings are parallel.

elements.content: There exist two crystallographically independent nickel ions (Ni(1) and Ni(2)), a pdc3− ligand, one and a half bth ligands and two coordinated water molecules in the asymmetric unit (Figure ). As in 1 and 3, the linear trinuclear Ni(II) units exist with a Ni(1)···Ni(2) distance of 4.502(4) Å, in which the largest deviation is 0.056 Å for the Ni(2) atom from the mean plane defined by the pyrazole rings. The Ni(1) and Ni(2) centers have the distorted octahedral coordination environments and are both six-coordinated. Each linear trinuclear Ni(II) unit is connected with the other six trinuclear Ni(II) units through six bth ligands to construct a 3D architecture (Figure ). The 3D structure can also be rationalized as a 6-connected uninodal (44.610.8) topological network (the long Schläfli symbol is 4.4.4.4.65.67.611.62.64.611.64.65.62.67.*) by considering the linear trinuclear Ni(II) units as 6-connected nodes and the bth ligands as linkers (Figure ), respectively. Interestingly, it represents an example of six-connected self-penetration. Different from the six-connected self-penetrated complex {[Sc(L)3](CF3SO3)3(CH3OH)2.7(H2O)3}∞ (L = 4,4′-bipyridine-N,N′-dioxide) with 48.66.8 topological symbol, each six-membered circuit in 5 is catenated by four instead of two equivalent circuits within the single framework. In 5, the bth ligands adopt two conformations: trans−trans−trans−trans−gauche (Scheme g) and trans−trans−trans−trans−trans (Scheme f). Furthermore, the framework of 5 is consolidated by extensive intramolecular hydrogen-bonding interactions ().

elements.content: Complexes 6 and 7 have a similar 3D framework; however, they crystallize in the chiral P212121 and the centro-symmetrical P21/c space group, respectively. Additionally, the two structures show distinguishable patterns in their simulated powder XRD (). The asymmetric units of 6 and 7 are depicted in Figure . Both Ni(II) and Zn(II) centers in 6 and 7 have distorted octahedral coordination environments and are coordinated by one oxygen atom from the water molecule, two nitrogen atoms from the bth ligands, one nitrogen atom, and two oxygen atoms from the Hpdc2− ligands. Although all the bth ligands in 6 and 7 adopt the gauche−trans−trans−trans−gauche (Scheme e) conformation, two kinds of crystallographically independent bth ligands exist in 7, but one in 6. The N(4)−N(5)−C(8)−C(9) and N(7)−N(8)−C(13)−C(14) torsion angles are 80.26(1) and 76.12(1)° for 6, 70.56(1) and 61.77(1)° for 7, respectively. The dihedral angles of the two triazole rings of the bth ligands are 20.59 and 180° in 6 and 7, respectively. The dihedral angle between the N(3)−C(6)−N(4)−N(5)−C(7) and N(6)−C(11)−N(7)−N(8)−C(12) triazole rings is 29.35° in 7. The N(5)−C(8)−C(9) and N(8)−C(13)−C(14) bond angles are 111.8(4) and 111.4(4)° for 6, 114.5(3) and 111.1(3)° for 7. The metal ions are linked by the bth ligands to form the sawtoothed 1D chains in both complexes, and only the chain in 6 is shown in Figure a. Interestingly, the slight difference in the conformations of the bth ligands leads to the single-stranded helical chains for 6 and meso-helical chains for 7, respectively, as shown in Figure . If the helical chain in 6 is projected in the ab plane, it is a ◯-shaped pattern. However, the projection drawing in the bc plane of the meso-helical chain is a lemniscate in 7. Assembly of infinite helical or meso-helical structures has been well understood and is controlled by several factors such as ligand conformational flexibility, supramolecular interactions, or solvent effects, etc. Tuning between the helical and the meso-helical forms in a structure has been reported. The helical chains and the meso-helical chains are connected by the Hpdc2− ligands to form a 3D chiral and meso-framework for 6 and 7, respectively, in which each Hpdc2− ligand in a μ3-η2N,O, η1O′′ fashion (Scheme c) bridges two metal ions by using only the one carboxylate group in a syn−anti mode to form an 1D chain with the close M···M (M = Ni or Zn) distance of 5.353(1) Å for 6, 5.439(1) Å for 7 (only the chain in 6 shown in Figure a). The 3D frameworks of 6 and 7 are similar and can also be simplified as a 4-connected uninodal 66 topological network (the long Schläfli symbol is 62.62.62.62.62.62) by considering the metal centers as 4-connected nodes and the bth and Hpdc2− ligands as linkers (Figure b), respectively. The structure of 7 contains solvated water molecules while no solvated water molecules exist in the structure of 6. The solvent-accessible space for the desolvated 7 is 4% of the total volume, calculated using the PLATON routine.

The metal ions are linked by the bth ligands to form the sawtoothed 1D chains in both complexes, and only the chain in 6 is shown in Figure a. Interestingly, the slight difference in the conformations of the bth ligands leads to the single-stranded helical chains for 6 and meso-helical chains for 7, respectively, as shown in Figure . If the helical chain in 6 is projected in the ab plane, it is a ◯-shaped pattern. However, the projection drawing in the bc plane of the meso-helical chain is a lemniscate in 7. Assembly of infinite helical or meso-helical structures has been well understood and is controlled by several factors such as ligand conformational flexibility, supramolecular interactions, or solvent effects, etc. Tuning between the helical and the meso-helical forms in a structure has been reported. The helical chains and the meso-helical chains are connected by the Hpdc2- ligands to form a 3D chiral and meso-framework for 6 and 7, respectively, in which each Hpdc2- ligand in a μ3-η2N,O, η1O'' fashion (Scheme c) bridges two metal ions by using only the one carboxylate group in a syn-anti mode to form an 1D chain with the close M⋅⋅⋅M (M = Ni or Zn) distance of 5.353(1) Å for 6, 5.439(1) Å for 7 (only the chain in 6 shown in Figure a). The 3D frameworks of 6 and 7 are similar and can also be simplified as a 4-connected uninodal 66 topological network (the long Schläfli symbol is 62.62.62.62.62.62) by considering the metal centers as 4-connected nodes and the bth and Hpdc2- ligands as linkers (Figure b), respectively. The structure of 7 contains solvated water molecules while no solvated water molecules exist in the structure of 6. The solvent-accessible space for the desolvated 7 is 4% of the total volume, calculated using the PLATON routine.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of complexes 1, 3, 5, and 6 have been measured for polycrystalline samples in the temperature range of 1.8-300 K under a 2000 Oe applied magnetic field, as shown in Figure .

elements.content: Temperature dependences of the χM (◻) and χM T (▽) curves for complexes 1 (a), 3 (b) and 5 (c), the χM T (▽) curve (d) and M vs H plot measured at 1.8 K (inset) for 6. The solid lines represent the best fit obtained with the parameters indicated in the text.
elements.clean_text: 14  Temperature dependences of the χM (◻) and χM T (▽) curves for complexes 1 (a), 3 (b) and 5 (c), the χM T (▽) curve (d) and M vs H plot measured at 1.8 K (inset) for 6. The solid lines represent the best fit obtained with the parameters indicated in the text.

elements.content: At 300 K, the χM T values of 1, 3 and 5 are 3.63, 4.03, and 3.71 cm3 K mol−1, respectively, which is higher than the expected value of 3.0 cm3 K mol−1 for three isolated nickel(II) (S = 1) species with a g factor of 2. This difference might be caused by the spin−orbit coupling characteristic for nickel(II) complexes with an 3A2g ground state. There is a continuous decrease in the values of χM T as the temperature is lowered from 300 to 1.8 K, at which point the χM T values are 0.910 cm3 K mol−1 for 1, 0.87 cm3 K mol−1 for 3, and 0.98 cm3 K mol−1 for 5, indicating dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Ni(II) ions within the trinuclear cluster unit coupled through the pyrazole nitrogen atoms. The experimental data for 1, 3, and 5 were modeled in the range from 300 to 1.8 K using eq deduced from the Hamiltonian H = −2J(S 1 S 2 + S 1 S 3) for a simple linear trinuclear cluster model as shown in Scheme , where J is the exchange interaction between adjacent nickel(II) ions in the trinuclear cluster units, and S i is the spin operate for each Ni(II) ion (S = 1). A satisfactory fit was obtained with the parameters g = 2.21 ± 0.01, J = −1.51 ± 0.03 cm−1 for 1, g = 2.34 ± 0.01, J = −2.01 ± 0.07 for 3, g = 2.18 ± 0.01, J = −2.49 ± 0.09 cm−1 for 5, confirming the antiferromagnetic interactions. The g values are reasonable, falling near the range of 2.0−2.4 for octahedral nickel(II). Antiferromagnetic exchange ranging from weak to moderate is quite frequently observed in pyrazole bridged dinuclear Ni(II) and Cu(II) systems and trinuclear Cu(II) systems.

At room temperature, the χM T value for 6 is 1.18 cm3 K mol−1, slightly larger than the spin-only value (1.0 cm3 K mol−1) for per uncorrelated Ni(II) center (S = 1). Upon cooling from 300 to 40 K, the χM T values remain almost constant. From 40 to 1.8 K, it increases rapidly and reaches a maximum of 1.57 cm3 K mol−1 at 1.8 K (Figure d), indicating the presence of ferromagnetic interactions. Since the distance between the neighboring Ni(II) ions linked by bth ligands is 12.489 Å and is too long for significant magnetic interactions, the ferromagnetic Ni(II)···Ni(II) exchange interaction is transmitted through the bridging carboxylate group of Hpdc2− in a syn−anti mode. The fitting of experimental data using eq for the infinite uniform 1D Ni(II) chain leads to J = 0.66 ± 0.01 cm−1 and g = 2.16 ± 0.01, confirming the ferromagnetic interactions in 6. Magnetization versus field measurements at 1.8 K (the inset in Figure d) shows the saturation value of 2.02 Nμ B at 7 T, which is close to the expected value (2 Nμ B). The results also suggest that ferromagnetic interactions exist in complex 6. χ Μ = 2 N g 2 β 2 3 k T × 0.14709 − 0.788967 k T / J + 0.866426 ( k T / J ) 2 + ( k T / J ) 3 0.096573 k T / J − 0.624929 ( k T / J ) 2 + ( k T / J ) 3

elements.content: TGA measurements are performed for crystalline samples of 1−3, 5, and 6 in the temperature range of 25−750 °C (Figure ). A weight loss of 9.18% in 25−185 °C corresponds to the release of five coordinated water molecules (calculated 9.24%) for complex 1. The further weight loss is ascribed to the release of the last one coordinated water molecule and the combustion of the organic ligands pdc2− and btb and the residual weight is 23.76% (calculated 22.99%). For 2, the weight loss in the range of 180−230 °C is related to the loss of two coordinated aqua molecules (5.63% weight loss observed; 5.4% calculated). From 80 to 190 °C, the weight loss of 14.26% for 3 is attributed to the loss of the eight coordinated water molecules (calculated 14.52%). For 5, the decomposition is observed at ca. 190 °C and the residual weight is 17.91% (calculated 18.44%). The loss of one coordinated water molecule for 6 occurs between 29 and 60 °C (4.75% weight loss observed; 3.99% calculated).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses

TGA measurements are performed for crystalline samples of 1-3, 5, and 6 in the temperature range of 25-750 °C (Figure ). A weight loss of 9.18% in 25-185 °C corresponds to the release of five coordinated water molecules (calculated 9.24%) for complex 1. The further weight loss is ascribed to the release of the last one coordinated water molecule and the combustion of the organic ligands pdc2- and btb and the residual weight is 23.76% (calculated 22.99%). For 2, the weight loss in the range of 180-230 °C is related to the loss of two coordinated aqua molecules (5.63% weight loss observed; 5.4% calculated). From 80 to 190 °C, the weight loss of 14.26% for 3 is attributed to the loss of the eight coordinated water molecules (calculated 14.52%). For 5, the decomposition is observed at ca. 190 °C and the residual weight is 17.91% (calculated 18.44%). The loss of one coordinated water molecule for 6 occurs between 29 and 60 °C (4.75% weight loss observed; 3.99% calculated).

elements.content: In summary, the self-assembly reactions of the flexible bis(triazolyl) ligands (1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane, btb; or 1,6-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)hexane, bth) and zinc(II) or nickel(II) salts with the auxiliary ligand, 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid (H3pdc) produce seven coordination polymers under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions. The flexibility of btb and bth, the diversity of the coordination mode of H3pdc (Scheme ) and the different coordination preferences of the Ni(II) and Zn(II) metal ions lead cooperatively to the different architectures from 1D chains to 3D structures. Three coordination modes for the H3pdc ligand and three conformations for bth ligands are observed in these complexes; however, btb ligands display only one conformation, which shows that the longer the alkyl chain is, more flexible the bis(triazolyl) ligand is. In complex 5, two different conformations of bth are observed, which induces an interesting six-connected self-catenated 3D framework with 44.610.8 topology. The flexibility of the bth ligands in conformations produces chiral complex 6 and mesomeric complex 7, respectively. Magnetic properties for complexes 1, 3, 5, and 6 have been studied and ferromagnetic interactions are observed for 6.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, the self-assembly reactions of the flexible bis(triazolyl) ligands (1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane, btb; or 1,6-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)hexane, bth) and zinc(II) or nickel(II) salts with the auxiliary ligand, 3,5-pyrazoledicarboxylic acid (H3pdc) produce seven coordination polymers under hydrothermal or solvothermal conditions. The flexibility of btb and bth, the diversity of the coordination mode of H3pdc (Scheme ) and the different coordination preferences of the Ni(II) and Zn(II) metal ions lead cooperatively to the different architectures from 1D chains to 3D structures. Three coordination modes for the H3pdc ligand and three conformations for bth ligands are observed in these complexes; however, btb ligands display only one conformation, which shows that the longer the alkyl chain is, more flexible the bis(triazolyl) ligand is. In complex 5, two different conformations of bth are observed, which induces an interesting six-connected self-catenated 3D framework with 44.610.8 topology. The flexibility of the bth ligands in conformations produces chiral complex 6 and mesomeric complex 7, respectively. Magnetic properties for complexes 1, 3, 5, and 6 have been studied and ferromagnetic interactions are observed for 6.

Synthesis of {[Zn(Hpdc)(bth)(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (7)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.2 mmol, 59.4 mg), H3pdc (0.2 mmol, 34.8 mg), bth (0.2 mmol, 44.0 mg), and H2O (8 mL) was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined bomb and heated at 180 °C for 3 days. The reaction mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C/30 min. Colorless block crystals of 7 suitable for XRD analysis were isolated in 57% yield. Anal. calcd. for C15H24N8O7Zn: C, 36.49; H, 4.90; N, 22.69%. Found: C, 36.40; H, 4.80; N, 22.76%. IR (KBr)/cm-1: 3415 s, 1617 s, 1570 m, 1522 w.

cln_elements.content:
At room temperature, the χM T value for 6 is 1.18 cm3 K mol−1, slightly larger than the spin-only value (1.0 cm3 K mol−1) for per uncorrelated Ni(II) center (S = 1). Upon cooling from 300 to 40 K, the χM T values remain almost constant. From 40 to 1.8 K, it increases rapidly and reaches a maximum of 1.57 cm3 K mol−1 at 1.8 K (Figure d), indicating the presence of ferromagnetic interactions. Since the distance between the neighboring Ni(II) ions linked by bth ligands is 12.489 Å and is too long for significant magnetic interactions, the ferromagnetic Ni(II)···Ni(II) exchange interaction is transmitted through the bridging carboxylate group of Hpdc2− in a syn−anti mode. The fitting of experimental data using eq for the infinite uniform 1D Ni(II) chain leads to J = 0.66 ± 0.01 cm−1 and g = 2.16 ± 0.01, confirming the ferromagnetic interactions in 6. Magnetization versus field measurements at 1.8 K (the inset in Figure d) shows the saturation value of 2.02 Nμ B at 7 T, which is close to the expected value (2 Nμ B). The results also suggest that ferromagnetic interactions exist in complex 6. χ Μ = 2 N g 2 β 2 3 k T × 0.14709 − 0.788967 k T / J + 0.866426 ( k T / J ) 2 + ( k T / J ) 3 0.096573 k T / J − 0.624929 ( k T / J ) 2 + ( k T / J ) 3

Thermogravimetric Analyses

TGA measurements are performed for crystalline samples of 1−3, 5, and 6 in the temperature range of 25−750 °C (Figure ). A weight loss of 9.18% in 25−185 °C corresponds to the release of five coordinated water molecules (calculated 9.24%) for complex 1. The further weight loss is ascribed to the release of the last one coordinated water molecule and the combustion of the organic ligands pdc2− and btb and the residual weight is 23.76% (calculated 22.99%). For 2, the weight loss in the range of 180−230 °C is related to the loss of two coordinated aqua molecules (5.63% weight loss observed; 5.4% calculated). From 80 to 190 °C, the weight loss of 14.26% for 3 is attributed to the loss of the eight coordinated water molecules (calculated 14.52%). For 5, the decomposition is observed at ca. 190 °C and the residual weight is 17.91% (calculated 18.44%). The loss of one coordinated water molecule for 6 occurs between 29 and 60 °C (4.75% weight loss observed; 3.99% calculated).
